Subject: Re: [junit] Contribution idea: assertions that directly support Java 8's Optional

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Stefan,

Thank you for the link. After a cursory glance, it seems like digg=
ing into Hamcrest to assert that an optional value is empty, for example, i=
s more work for the user than it=E2=80=99s worth. I would rather stick to D=
avid=E2=80=99s suggestion of assertEquals(x, Optional.empty()) for this cas=
e, unless the assertion was especially complex. Then, as I mentioned to Dav=
id, that isn=E2=80=99t nearly as clean (in my opinion) as an assertEmpty wo=
uld be.

Best,
Mark


> On Oct 5, 2015, at 12:18 AM, Stefan Bechtold stefan=
.bechtold@... [junit] <junit@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> 
> Hi Mark
> 
=
> Actually, I think this sounds more as an addition to a matcher framework =
like hamcrest rather than an addition to JUnit itself. What do you think? 
=
> 
> see also: https://github.com/hamcrest/JavaHamcrest/issues/82 <https://=
github.com/hamcrest/JavaHamcrest/issues/82>
> 
> all the best
> 
> Stefan
>=
 
> 
> Am 04.10.2015 um 19:55 schrieb Mark Silvis masilvis22@... <mai=
lto:masilvis22@...> [junit] <junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit@yaho=
ogroups.com>>:
> 
>>  
>> I would like to contribute to JUnit, and I think =
I have a good idea for a feature. I=E2=80=99ve found that it would be nice =
to have assertions that explicitly supported Java 8=E2=80=99s Optional clas=
s. I=E2=80=99m thinking something along the lines of assertEmpty() and asse=
rtPresent(). Would such an addition be welcomed?
>> 
>> Thanks,
>> Mark
>> =

> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_DC7312E4-F20E-477D-9E75-B9F9F4AD6C03
